143347.name: We Walk As One: The Grand Opening

venue.name: Centre 200
venue.google_maps_link: https://maps.google.com/?q=481 George Street Sydney, NS B1P 6R7 Canada

143347.description_public: Celtic Colours kicks off its 21st year with a return to Centre 200. Featuring some well-known names alongside a few new faces, this concert sets the tone for the “week” to come with some truly outstanding players, singers and dancers. Tonight we’ll see artists from Scotland, Ireland, Nunavut, and from right here at home. It is very exciting to welcome Michael McGoldrick and John McCusker to Celtic Colours. Along with past Artist in Residence John Doyle, they will be making their Cape Breton debut as a trio. This will also be Festival debuts for throat-singer IVA from Nunavut and Cape Breton’s own Heather Rankin. Scottish Gaelic singer Cathy Ann MacPhee and Cape Breton supergroup Còig are returning this year along with La Swing du Suête dancers from Chéticamp to round out this Grand Opening concert. Nearby Meal: Whitney Pier Roast Beef Dinner

484751.bio_limited: After more than twenty-five years of performing with her siblings, Heather Rankin comes into her own with A Fine Line, her JUNO-nominated debut solo record. This is Heather Rankin like you have never heard her before, breaking away from The Rankin Family’s signature sound, and forging her own musical legacy with her poetic, intimate original songs, and an eclectic mix of others. A Fine Line is an exploration of the balance between grief and joy, love and loss, and life and death. It is also a balance between Heather's musical past, present and future. Her voice has been shaped by the Gaelic traditions of her home, and by the years she spent singing the songs of her brothers and sisters, but her voice is set free here, suggesting that we are only just now getting to know Heather Rankin. She has always been known as the youngest of The Rankin Family, but now, as a solo artist, in some ways, she sounds younger, and more timely, than ever.

484751.secondary_language_bio: After more than twenty-five years of performing with her siblings, Heather Rankin comes into her own with A Fine Line, her JUNO-nominated debut solo record. This is Heather Rankin like you have never heard her before, breaking away from The Rankin Family’s signature sound, and forging her own musical legacy with her poetic, intimate original songs, and an eclectic mix of others. A Fine Line is an exploration of the balance between grief and joy, love and loss, and life and death. It is also a balance between her own musical past, present and future. Her voice has been shaped by the Gaelic traditions of her home, and by the years she spent singing the songs of her brothers and sisters, but her voice is set free here, and often euphorically so, in a way previously unheard. Proving eloquent songwriting runs in the family, Rankin takes us to more private places in her lyrics, and this mixture of vulnerability and exhilaration makes for a powerfully compelling record. After more than twenty-five years in the business, A Fine Line suggests that we are only just now getting to know Heather Rankin. She has always been known as the youngest of The Rankin Family, but now, as a solo artist, in some ways, she sounds younger, and more timely, than ever.Heather makes her Celtic Colours debut this year.

471643.bio_limited: From touring with the likes of Bob Dylan, Mark Knopfler and Joan Baez to being founding or long-time members of legendary groups Flook, Lunasa, Battlefield Band and Solas, Michael McGoldrick, John McCusker and John Doyle have been at the forefront of traditional and folk music for decades. Key members of the acclaimed BBC Transatlantic Sessions, the trio has recently released their second record, giving us all a rare chance to see three of the world’s finest musicians share a stage together. Master of flutes, whistles and uillean pipes McGoldrick is a founding member of Flook and Lunasa, and is a current member of Capercaillie. Regarded as one of the greatest flute players of all time, McGoldrick has toured with Bob Dylan and Mark Knopfler, among many others. John McCusker’s unique fiddle playing has earned him a worldwide reputation as one of the most gifted and versatile musicians of any genre. Renowned for his skill at transcending musical boundaries, McCusker—also part of the band that toured with Dylan and Knopfler—spent 11 years touring the world with the legendary Battlefield Band. John Doyle’s gifts as guitarist, songwriter and vocalist have played an essential role in the ongoing renaissance of Irish traditional music. A past Artist in Residence at Celtic Colours (2012), Doyle was musical director for Joan Baez and toured with her for two years. One half of the stellar duo Liz Carroll and John Doyle, he is also a founding member of the internationally acclaimed Irish group Solas.

470881.bio_limited: Chrissy Crowley, Rachel Davis, Jason Roach and Darren McMullen got together in 2010 for a tour promoting Celtic Colours. An engaging line-up of well-known solo acts—featuring expertly-played fiddle, piano, guitar, mandolin, whistle and banjo—they enjoyed playing together so much that they decided to continue to perform as Còig whenever their busy solo careers allowed. And in one explosive coming together, what was once solo acts on stage has amalgamated into one electrifying super group. With their driving tunes, haunting songs and infectious energy, Còig has proven to be a serious force to be reckoned with on the traditional music scene. Their debut album was released in 2014 to rave reviews, and has earned the band a Canadian Folk Music Award, a Music Nova Scotia Award, and the 2015 East Coast Music Award for Roots/Traditional Group Recording of the Year. The band released their latest album, Rove, in June.

470881.name: Còig
470881.secondary_language_bio:
Còig, one of Atlantic Canada's premiere traditional groups, is an ensemble of East Coast musicians originally forming to promote the Celtic Colours International Festival. In one explosive coming together, what was once solo acts on stage has amalgamated into one electrifying super group, picked as Penguin Eggs magazine’s 2014 #1 New Discovery internationally. With the fiery Celtic style as its musical core, Còig easily shifts between century old tunes of past generations to original and contemporary compositions, featuring the band’s range of over a dozen instruments (vocals, fiddles, piano, guitar, banjo, mandolin, viola, bouzouki, whistles, and more). With driving tunes, haunting songs, and infectious energy, Còig is an unparalleled musical force.
Fiddler Chrissy Crowley, from Margaree, Cape Breton has an impressive list of awards, nominations, and international appearances. Chrissy embraces her Celtic roots and makes them her own, through original compositions coupled with contemporary arrangements of traditional tunes.
Darren McMullen, from Hardwood Lands, NS, is a highly sought after multi-instrumentalist. Easily switching between guitar, mandolin, whistle and banjo with Còig, this "Swiss-army knife" keeps the rhythm sound diverse, and is sure to impress with his lead playing of his various “on-stage weapons”.
Rachel Davis from Baddeck, Cape Breton spends her time switching from international festival stages to small local dances at home. In a genre that sees many performers pushing the envelope and testing new waters, her style of playing traditional tunes in a traditional way is a refreshing reminder of why the Cape Breton fiddle style drives so hard, and is so sought after.
Jason Roach, from Chéticamp, Cape Breton is one of the most impressive piano players you will ever hear. With a style all his own, and an unparalleled intensity on the keys, you'll have to remind yourself that there's other players on the stage.
With a combined total of over 30 nominations and awards, each of Còig’s talented musicians have released their own successful solo albums, and have toured both at home and abroad before coming together as this exciting super group. Their much anticipated debut album "Five" was released in June, 2014 to rave reviews, and has earned the band the 2014 Canadian Folk Music Award for Traditional Album of the Year, the Music Nova Scotia Award for Traditional/Roots Recording of the Year, and most recently, the 2015 East Coast Music Award for Roots/Traditional Group Recording of the Year.

And in one explosive coming together, what was once solo acts on stage has amalgamated into one electrifying super group. With their driving tunes, haunting songs and infectious energy, Còig has proven to be a serious force to be reckoned with on the traditional music scene. Their debut album was released in 2014 to rave reviews, and has earned the band a Canadian Folk Music Award, a Music Nova Scotia Award, and the 2015 East Coast Music Award for Roots/Traditional Group Recording of the Year. The band released their latest album, Rove, in June.

470764.bio_limited: Cathy Ann and Patsy have been friends and musical collaborators since meeting at the first Fèis on the island of Barra in 1981. They have both pursued very varied careers since then. Cathy Ann has sung at many places from small village halls on her native island of Barra to major concert halls and is an inspiration to the ever growing tide of fans of Gaelic music. She has also acted in numerous theatre shows in Gaelic and English and has often appeared on TV. Patsy is a clàrsach player and singer and is best known for her work with the harp duo Sileas, the band The Poozies, the supergroup Clan Alba and many appearances with other performers. She is also an active teacher and with her role as Artistic Adviser for the Edinburgh International Harp Festival has helped nurture the next generation of Scottish harp players. Cathy Ann and Patsy can both be heard on numerous CD and radio recordings. They come together periodically to share their love of Gaelic music and song and are delighted to be sharing their music at Celtic Colours.

470615.bio_limited: La Swing du Suête initially came together in 1997 for the first annual Cape Breton Dance Festival in Chéticamp. Over the last twenty years, La Swing du Suête has presented itself across the Maritime provinces as well as in Quebec, Alberta and Louisiana, USA. Under the artistic direction of Christine Doucet and Sylvie Aucoin, the troupe continues to enchant audiences with their choreographies, their dance steps, and particularly their charm. This troupe is comprised of dancers ranging in age from 10 to 17 all students at École NDA in Chéticamp. Celtic Colours celebrates the group's 20th anniversary in the annual dance show in Cheticamp, Dancing Up a Suête and in the opening show, We Walk as One.

488978.bio_limited: Kathleen Ivaluarjuk Merritt also known as IVA (ee-vah) will take you on a journey through the Arctic with vocal interpretations of the wind, birds, landscape and sea. Iva is a throat-singer, poet, writer and collaborator from Rankin Inlet, Nunavut who performs a melodic mix of Inuit throat singing and poetry infused with Celtic-influenced folk. Her 2015 debut album, Ivaluarjuk: Ice, Lines & Sealskin, celebrates life and identity; bridging sounds from both her Inuit and Irish roots. The music reaches a wide-range of sounds, crossing multiple genres that come together charmingly to transport audiences to the coasts of Cape Breton and Nunavut. When she is home in Nunavut, IVA works in schools and music programs to teach throat singing and facilitate workshops that encourage youth to create and collaborate, and build on their skills and confidence through music, art and identity.

148185.venue_name: Colaisde na Gàidhlig / The Gaelic College

venue.name: Colaisde na Gàidhlig / The Gaelic College
venue.google_maps_link: https://maps.google.com/?q=51779 Cabot Trail  St. Ann's, NS B0C 1H0 Canada

148185.description_public: One of the most popular features of the Celtic Colours International Festival every year is the Festival Club. Located at the Gaelic College in St. Ann's, the licensed Festival Club opens as the evening concerts are closing, offering an opportunity for artists to showcase in a more informal setting, as well as get a session in with friends and colleagues from near and far. It also serves as a spot to wind down at the end of the day. Performance is by invitation only and depends upon artist availability on any given night. The performance schedule is not posted in advance. North Shore singer-songwriter Buddy MacDonald hosts the nightly festivities. Tickets are $10 for the first night only. *Restricted to 19 years and over. Picture ID required

143348.name: Along the Shores of Bras d'Or
143348.venue_name: Big Pond Community Centre / Fire Hall

venue.name: Big Pond Community Centre / Fire Hall
venue.google_maps_link: https://maps.google.com/?q=7193 NS Highway 4 Big Pond, NS B1J 1V2 Canada

143348.description_public: Big Pond is a community with a rich legacy of traditional tunes and celebrated songwriters. This concert reflects the place of importance music holds in the area. Blanche Sophocleous is a singer and guitar- player from Big Pond who performed in the folk group Sons of Skye during the 1970s and ‘80s. Rachel Davis and Darren McMullen, bandmates in Còig, make a lovely duo with Rachel’s singing and fiddling and Darren’s mastery of every other instrument. Howie MacDonald and Hilda Chiasson will add some lively tunes and we welcome singer-songwriter Garnet Rogers who makes his first appearance at Celtic Colours this afternoon. Take your time getting to this one and don’t miss the lovely views along the shores of the Bras d’Or. Nearby Meal: Baked Ham and Potato Scallop Supper

492179.bio_limited: Born in Hamilton, Ontario to parents of Nova Scotian descent, Garnet Rogers spent many hours in front of the old floor model radio listening to Grand Ol' Opry broadcasts and harmonizing with his brother, the late folk legend Stan Rogers. Barely out of high school, Garnet Rogers was on the road as a full-time working musician with his older brother Stan. Together they formed what has come to be accepted as one of the most influential acts in North American folk music. Since then, Garnet has established himself as one of the major talents of our time. A charismatic performer and singer, Garnet casts a powerful physical presence with a voice to match. His music, like the man himself, is literate, passionate, highly sensitive, and deeply purposeful. Cinematic in detail, his songs give expression to the unspoken vocabulary of the heart. It is our pleasure to welcome Garnet to Celtic Colours for the first time.

470404.bio_limited: Howie MacDonald is a well-respected fiddler from Westmount, Cape Breton County. He has been a performer as long as he can remember. Whether at a family gathering or an international concert hall, Howie's job was always to entertain. Coming from a musical family, he has released 11 albums and a DVD and spent many years touring and recording with the Rankin Family. Howie has expanded his talents and gained popularity as a comedian recently for his roles in musical comedy revues Island Mania, Howie's Celtic Brew, The Dance Last Night, and the Cape Breton Summertime Revue. An accomplished piano player who has accompanied just about everyone on the island, Howie is also very much in demand for dances, concerts, ceilidhs and recording sessions. He takes great inspiration from the tunes and musicians from prior generations, greatly inspired by musicians such as Winston "Scotty" Fitzgerald. Always involved in key shows for the festival, Howie will take part in the tribute show to good friend Dave MacIsaac this year.
470404.bio_public: Howie MacDonald is a well-respected fiddler from Westmount, Cape Breton County. He has been a performer as long as he can remember. Whether at a family gathering or an international concert hall, Howie's job was always to entertain. Coming from a musical family, he has released 11 albums and a DVD and spent many years touring and recording with the Rankin Family. Howie has expanded his talents and gained popularity as a comedian recently for his roles in musical comedy revues Island Mania, Howie's Celtic Brew, The Dance Last Night, and the Cape Breton Summertime Revue. An accomplished piano player who has accompanied just about everyone on the island, Howie is also very much in demand for dances, concerts, ceilidhs and recording sessions. He takes great inspiration from the tunes and musicians from prior generations, greatly inspired by musicians such as Winston "Scotty" Fitzgerald. Always involved in key shows for the festival, Howie will take part in the tribute show to good friend Dave MacIsaac this year.
470404.name: Howie MacDonald
470404.secondary_language_bio:
Howie has been a performer as long as he can remember. Whether at a family gathering or an international concert hall, Howie's job was always to entertain. Even while spending many years touring and recording with the Rankin Family, Howie still managed to release nine albums.

Over the past couple of years, Howie has expanded his talents and gained popularity as a comedian. He has appeared in the Cape Breton Summertime Revue, a mainstage showcase for the East Coast Music Awards, Nancy White's Joke Box, Howie's Celtic Brew, The Rise & Follies of Cape Breton: The Second Coming and has most recently reprised his role in Island Mania, a new musical and comedy revue running for its second year at the Savoy Theatre. Howie is an accomplished piano player as well and has accompanied just about everyone on the island.

470580.bio_limited: Hilda Chiasson is one of the most sought after piano players of this generation and has played on more than 50 recordings in Canada, Ireland, Scotland, Denmark and the USA. A native of Chéticamp where she played for dances and recorded since she was a teenager, Hilda is also a very good step dancer and has played and recorded with a who's who of Cape Breton fiddlers including Winston 'Scotty' Fitzgerald, Donald Angus Beaton, Jerry Holland, Carl MacKenzie and J.P. Cormier. Hilda has performed throughout Canada, the USA, Scotland, Ireland and Denmark as well as in Dubai, Bahrain, and Afghanistan. Hilda has been a mainstay on our Celtic Colours' stages, performing year after year and in some of our most pivotal shows!

470428.bio_limited: Since being presented the Tic Butler Memorial Award during Celtic Colours in 2007, Rachel Davis’ music career has taken off. The fiddler and singer from Baddeck, was chosen as the 2009 recipient of the Frank "Big Sampie" Sampson award, leading to the release of her debut album that year. She released her second album, Turns, in 2013 and was nominated for a Canadian Folk Music Award. A dynamic player with great timing and a great lift to her music, Rachel is often called upon to share the stage with singer-songwriters like Buddy MacDonald, Carmel Mikol and Donnie Campbell. Rachel is a founding member of Cape Breton supergroup Coìg, who released their debut album in 2014 and these days she spends her time between international festival stages and small local dances around home. In a genre that sees many performers pushing the envelope and testing new waters, her style of playing traditional tunes in a traditional way is a refreshing reminder of why the Cape Breton fiddle style drives so hard, and is so sought after.

470428.name: Rachel Davis
470428.secondary_language_bio:
Since being presented the Tic Butler Memorial Award during Celtic Colours in 2007, Rachel Davis’ music career has taken off. The fiddler and singer from Baddeck, who learned to play initially from her grandfather and continued with Karen Beaton, Stan Chapman and Kyle MacNeil through her studies at Cape Breton University, was chosen as the 2009 recipient of the Frank "Big Sampy" Sampson award, leading to the release of her debut album that year. A founding member of Cape Breton supergroup Coìg, Rachel released her second album, "Turns", in April of 2013 and was nominated for a Canadian Folk Music Award. 

Rachel Davis from Baddeck, Cape Breton spends her time switching from international festival stages to small local dances at home. In a genre that sees many performers pushing the envelope and testing new waters, her style of playing traditional tunes in a traditional way is a refreshing reminder of why the Cape Breton fiddle style drives so hard, and is so sought after.

Strongly influenced by the playing of her grandfather, Clarence Long, Baddeck native Rachel Davis has been a student of the fiddle since she was twelve. She fondly recalls sitting in a corner of her grandfather’s barber shop, squeaking away at tunes under his careful guidance. Those first efforts lead to more teachers (including Karen Beaton, Kyle MacNeil and Stan Chapman) and great progress, as she has developed into a dynamic player with great timing and a great lift to her music. Along with her solo work, Rachel is also in demand to share the stage with people such as singer-songwriters Buddy MacDonald, Carmel Mikol and Donnie Campbell, and has made guest appearances with groups such as The Cottars. Her latest collaboration is with the new Cape Breton powerhouse ensemble Còig, who released their debut album in 2014.

The fiddler and singer from Baddeck, was chosen as the 2009 recipient of the Frank "Big Sampie" Sampson award, leading to the release of her debut album that year. She released her second album, Turns, in 2013 and was nominated for a Canadian Folk Music Award. A dynamic player with great timing and a great lift to her music, Rachel is often called upon to share the stage with singer-songwriters like Buddy MacDonald, Carmel Mikol and Donnie Campbell. Rachel is a founding member of Cape Breton supergroup Coìg, who released their debut album in 2014 and these days she spends her time between international festival stages and small local dances around home. In a genre that sees many performers pushing the envelope and testing new waters, her style of playing traditional tunes in a traditional way is a refreshing reminder of why the Cape Breton fiddle style drives so hard, and is so sought after.

470839.bio_limited: Darren McMullen is a highly sought after multi-instrumentalist who plays primarily with Cape Breton supergroup Còig. His list of instruments includes mandolin, bouzouki, tenor banjo, whistles, guitar and bass, but he started young on piano. Darren played his way through the popular pub band scene until he landed a gig with J.P. Cormier in 2004 which took him throughout Canada, the USA and the UK Since then he has released three solo albums and been busy touring and performing as a sideman with a wide range of bands including the Rankin family, Matt Andersen, and many Cape Breton fiddlers. Being a founding member of popular Cape Breton band Còig keeps Darren very busy through the year, and when Còig is not busy, he maintains a permanent recording and touring position with David Francey.

490469.bio_limited: Blanche Sophocleous is a well-known vocalist, guitarist and Master of Ceremonies from Big Pond, Cape Breton. She was a member of the popular recording group Sons of Skye who toured Scotland and many provinces of Canada. Their album Both Sides of the Water, originally released on vinyl in 1981, was recently re-released on CD. She has also appeared on various albums as a back up guitarist for well known Cape Breton fiddlers and pianists. Blanche is also an emcee and entertainer on cruise ships, and at concerts, fashion shows and fundraisers.

143349.name: Pipes, Fiddles and Song: Pìobaireachd, Fìdhlearachd agus Òrain

venue.name: St. Matthew's United Church
venue.google_maps_link: https://maps.google.com/?q=78 Church Street Inverness, NS B0E 1N0 Canada

143349.description_public: The beauty of this church shines brightest in the daytime as sunlight pours through its stained glass windows. St. Matthew’s will be filled with tunes and songs today, shared among family and friends from Scotland and Cape Breton. Inverness County square dance royalty Kinnon and Betty will be joined by their daughter Andrea. Betty’s grand-nephew Joe, and Seudan—a group of four Scottish pipers and one of Mabou’s own—will ensure the pipes are well represented. Shelly Campbell, who embodies the Gaelic in her fiddle playing, will be accompanied by Allan Dewar on piano. And the voices of Joanne MacIntyre and her four teenaged sons will reach every pew with Gaelic song. Nearby Meal: Luncheon at the Arts Centre

470464.bio_limited: Kinnon Beaton has been playing the violin since 1968, a time when some worried that the music might be disappearing. Kinnon grew up in Mabou, Inverness County, listening to his parents (Donald Angus and Elizabeth) playing at home and for dances at the hall across the road. Fiddler and composer Dan R. MacDonald lived behind that hall and John Morris Rankin lived beside it; both frequently visited the Beaton home. Kinnon has taught workshops in Cape Breton, the USA and Scotland. He was first recorded on the family album The Beatons of Mabou, released by Rounder Records in 1978. He has played for countless dances, concerts and festivals throughout Canada, the USA and the UK, composed over 800 tunes, published three collection books, and recorded six albums. Kinnon is almost always accompanied by his wife Betty on piano.

Kinnon is almost always accompanied by his wife Betty on piano.
470464.name: Kinnon Beaton
470464.secondary_language_bio:
Kinnon Beaton has been playing the violin since 1968, a time when some worried that the music might be disappearing. Kinnon grew up in Mabou, NS, listening to his father Donald Angus (fiddler and composer) and mother (pianist) playing at home as well as playing for dances in the hall across the road. Fiddler and composer Dan R. MacDonald lived behind that hall and frequently visited the Beaton home. Kinnon's good friend, the late John Morris Rankin who was also moved by the same music, also lived nearby.

Kinnon has taught workshops at the Celtic Music Center in Judique, NS, at The Ceilidh Trail School of Music in Inverside, Cape Breton, at Fiddle Tunes in Port Townsend, Washington, USA and at Ceòlas in South Uist, Scotland. Kinnon has performed at numerous dances, concerts and festivals throughout Canada, the US, and the UK. He has composed over 700 tunes and published two collection books. Kinnon has appeared on numerous recordings, the first in 1978 Rounder Records released an album titled The Beaton's of Mabou where Donald Angus and Elizabeth were joined by their two sons, Joey (piano) and Kinnon (fiddle). In the eighties Kinnon and his wife Betty released three other recordings, Cape Breton Fiddle 1, Cape Breton Fiddle 2 and Sprig of Ivy which are now available on a compilation CD. A later recording produced by Kinnon was titled Saturday Night Lively where Kinnon and Betty were joined by their daughter Andrea (fiddle) as well as Joey (piano). The next CD, Cape Breton Fiddle and Piano Music from The Beaton Family of Mabou, a Smithsonian Folkways Recording featured Kinnon and his two nephews Rodney MacDonald and Glenn Graham, and Andrea on fiddles and Kinnon's mother Elizabeth, and wife Betty and sister Mary on pianos with dancing by Rodney MacDonald and another daughter Allison. Kinnon's CD called Eoghan Dubh is selections of Kinnon's own compositions.

Kinnon is almost always accompanied by his wife Betty, who also comes from a musical family being the sister of the widely known Cape Breton Fiddler, Buddy MacMaster and is the aunt of the widely traveled Natalie MacMaster. For 11 years, Kinnon was also owner/manager of his own Men's Wear Store in Port Hawkesbury, NS. and was the past Executive and Music Director at the Celtic Music Interpretive Centre in Judique, NS.

He was first recorded on the family album The Beatons of Mabou, released by Rounder Records in 1978. He has played for countless dances, concerts and festivals throughout Canada, the USA and the UK, composed over 800 tunes, published three collection books, and recorded six albums.
Kinnon is almost always accompanied by his wife Betty on piano.

470384.bio_limited: Betty Beaton began playing the piano at the age of five. Although she has a couple of years of piano training, all her Cape Breton piano playing is done by ear. At 14 years of age, she started playing dances with her brother Buddy MacMaster and has been accompanying fiddlers for dancers ever since. Betty taught at Colaisde na Gàidhlig / the Gaelic College in St. Ann's last summer and has also taught at the Ceilidh Trail School of Music in Inverside Cape Breton, at Fiddle Tunes in Port Townsend in Washington, USA, and Ceolas in South Uist, Scotland. She has played on numerous recordings including the Smithsonian Folkways recording The Beaton Family of Mabou: Cape Breton Fiddle and Piano Music and, most recently, her daughter Andrea's 2016 release Andrea Beaton with Betty and Dave. Betty is most often paired with her husband, fiddler Kinnon Beaton, and the duo is always in demand to play for dances.

470382.bio_limited: Andrea Beaton comes from a long line of musicians, composers and dancers. She is an award-winning fiddler, tune composer and recording artist who is known for her powerful bow and driving style. She tours and teaches internationally and is in great demand as a teacher at music camps and fiddling/dancing workshops. Andrea has released six solo albums, one duo album with her father, Kinnon Beaton, and published three books of her original tunes. She also recorded an album with her family The Beaton Family of Mabou in 2007 for the Smithsonian Institute. Most of her solo albums were nominated for awards, including her latest, Andrea Beaton with Betty and Dave (2016), and her 2010 CD, Branches, won the East Coast Music Award for Instrumental Recording of the Year. Andrea travels the globe, sharing her culture as well as exploring and writing contemporary tunes. Her music, dance and comical stories are sure to delight any audience.

470688.bio_limited: Seudan, founded by Hamish Moore, features the Scottish piping prowess of Fin Moore, Angus MacKenzie (originally of Mabou, Cape Breton), Angus Nicolson, Calum MacCrimmon, and Allan MacDonald. Pronounced "Shay-tan", the group consists of four vibrant young Highland bagpipers, anchored by the traditional piper and Gaelic singer Allan MacDonald, who comes from a well-revered piping family, rich in culture. Together they offer lively pipe music, rooted in the step dance traditions, now revived in Scotland with the indispensable help and inspiration of the unbroken line of the tradition in Cape Breton.

470432.bio_limited: Born and raised on West Bay Road, Inverness County, Shelly has been playing traditional Cape Breton music for almost 30 years. She was influenced by local fiddlers Stephanie Wills, Theresa MacLellan, Gertie Coffin and Alex Francis MacKay to name a few. Shelly plays at many local concerts, pubs and festivals and is a popular player for dances. Although she usually stays close to home, Shelly has taught and played throughout the Maritimes as well as in Ontario, Ireland, Scotland and Denmark. Shelly also has an avid interest in the Gaelic language and its preservation in Cape Breton and continues to work on her own fluency. She is currently teaching Junior High School math and science as well as Gaelic language grades 4-9. Shelly teaches private and group lessons and has been involved in the development and co-ordination of Fèis Cheap Breatuinn, which seeks to provide more opportunity for lessons and mentorship in traditional music, dance and language throughout Cape Breton. Shelly’s playing is powerful, lively and graceful, deeply rooted in the traditions she grew up listening to.

Shelly plays at many local concerts, pubs and festivals and is a popular player for dances. Although she usually stays close to home, Shelly has taught and played throughout the Maritimes as well as in Ontario, Ireland, Scotland and Denmark. Shelly also has an avid interest in the Gaelic language and its preservation in Cape Breton and continues to work on her own fluency. She is currently teaching Junior High School math and science as well as Gaelic language grades 4-9. Shelly teaches private and group lessons and has been involved in the development and co-ordination of Fèis Cheap Breatuinn, which seeks to provide more opportunity for lessons and mentorship in traditional music, dance and language throughout Cape Breton. Shelly’s playing is powerful, lively and graceful, deeply rooted in the traditions she grew up listening to.
470432.name: Shelly Campbell
470432.bio_with_line_breaks: Born and raised on West Bay Road, Inverness County, Shelly has been playing traditional Cape Breton music for almost 30 years. She was influenced by local fiddlers Stephanie Wills, Theresa MacLellan, Gertie Coffin and Alex Francis MacKay to name a few. Shelly plays at many local concerts, pubs and festivals and is a popular player for dances. Although she usually stays close to home, Shelly has taught and played throughout the Maritimes as well as in Ontario, Ireland, Scotland and Denmark. Shelly also has an avid interest in the Gaelic language and its preservation in Cape Breton and continues to work on her own fluency. She is currently teaching Junior High School math and science as well as Gaelic language grades 4-9. Shelly teaches private and group lessons and has been involved in the development and co-ordination of Fèis Cheap Breatuinn, which seeks to provide more opportunity for lessons and mentorship in traditional music, dance and language throughout Cape Breton. Shelly’s playing is powerful, lively and graceful, deeply rooted in the traditions she grew up listening to.

470448.bio_limited: Allan's background in the Cape Breton musical tradition is the backbone of his ability to accompany any fiddler, past and present—from Jerry Holland, Buddy MacMaster, Howie MacDonald, John Morris Rankin and John Pellerin to the new generation fiddlers including Troy MacGillivray, Andrea Beaton and Shelly Campbell—for dances and ceilidhs. Growing up in Halifax and Antigonish, Allan picked up the music at home.  There was no formal training of any sort, but folks like Dave MacIsaac and anyone who was in town for a Cape Breton dance would drop by the house for tunes. Allan learned by ear and he attended every concert, dance and house party he could. Allan has toured internationally with many musicians including Jerry Holland, Ashley MacIsaac, and Troy MacGillivray. Allan is Music Director at the Celtic Music Interpretive Centre in Judique and spends his leisure time accompanying local fiddlers at dances, concerts and ceilidhs.

470518.bio_limited: Joanne MacIntyre comes from Mabou Coal Mines, Inverness County where she was raised in a culture rich environment of Scotch music, dance and Gaelic language. She has sung on stages around Cape Breton since her teen years, bringing the island’s distinct style and “swing” to appreciative listening audiences. For five years, Joanne was a regular performer at Highland Village as a Gaelic singer, step dancer and story interpreter. She now teaches Gaelic language and Gaelic Studies at Dalbrae Academy in Mabou, passing on her knowledge and passion for the language and its attendant culture to younger generations. A Lochaber descendant, Joanne continues to expand her repertoire of songs from the Cape Breton and Inverness County Gaelic tradition. Joanne received the 2012 Big Sampie award and released her debut album of Gaelic songs, Craobh a’ Mhathain, during Celtic Colours 2013. Joanne is joined by her four teenage sons James, Stephen, Niall and Cameron, in keeping with the intergenerational transmission tradition of the Gaelic culture of Cape Breton.

470987.bio_limited: Deemed the newest powerhouse of Route 19 by Ashley MacIsaac, Joe MacMaster has quickly risen up the ranks of the Cape Breton music scene in the last number of years. With an arsenal of pipes, fiddle, and piano, Joe is known locally as a regular player at dances and ceilidhs in and around Cape Breton. He has toured through the USA performing with Natalie MacMaster, played for square dances in Ontario, and as of August 2017 will have performed in the Edmonton Folk Festival. Hailing from Troy, Inverness County, Joe is one of the younger members of the MacMaster fiddling dynasty. He credits his greatest musical influences as his grand-uncle Buddy MacMaster, his aunt Natalie MacMaster, Kenneth MacKenzie, and Mac Morin. Known for his traditional style and repertoire, Joe is also a composer with several noted tunes in circulation and was a part of Na Gaisgich Òga, and Féis Cape Breton, two programs geared towards developing Gaelic fluency, and traditional music skills in youth. He is a recent graduate of Dalbrae Academy in Mabou, and a new student of St. FX university.

143350.name: Còmhla Cruinn: Gathered Together

venue.name: Christmas Island Fire Hall
venue.google_maps_link: https://maps.google.com/?q=8539 NS Highway 223 Christmas Island, NS B1T 1B1 Canada

143350.description_public: Gaelic culture runs deep in Christmas Island where the traditions have been kept up for generations. Comunn Féis an Eilein has played a key role in maintaining the culture here, encouraging the community to preserve and promote their Gaelic roots. They host a Celtic Colours concert each year and have been presenting the annual Féis an Eilein since the early 1990s. Sarah MacInnis and Donna-Marie DeWolfe are talented young artists, both from families rooted in the Island’s culture. Cathy Ann MacPhee is one of the best Gaelic singers in the world, and we’re lucky to have her back. And Mabou natives Dawn and Margie Beaton, renowned for their harmonizing fiddles, will drive the tunes home this afternoon. Gather together with these fine performers for an afternoon of traditional and Gaelic influenced music and culture. Nearby Meal: Àros na Mara: Lunch and Learn

470764.bio_limited: Cathy Ann and Patsy have been friends and musical collaborators since meeting at the first Fèis on the island of Barra in 1981. They have both pursued very varied careers since then. Cathy Ann has sung at many places from small village halls on her native island of Barra to major concert halls and is an inspiration to the ever growing tide of fans of Gaelic music. She has also acted in numerous theatre shows in Gaelic and English and has often appeared on TV. Patsy is a clàrsach player and singer and is best known for her work with the harp duo Sileas, the band The Poozies, the supergroup Clan Alba and many appearances with other performers. She is also an active teacher and with her role as Artistic Adviser for the Edinburgh International Harp Festival has helped nurture the next generation of Scottish harp players. Cathy Ann and Patsy can both be heard on numerous CD and radio recordings. They come together periodically to share their love of Gaelic music and song and are delighted to be sharing their music at Celtic Colours.

470399.bio_limited: Dawn and Margie Beaton, from Mabou, were dancing at age four and started playing the fiddle a year later. Over the years they have performed at concerts, ceilidhs and festivals all around Cape Breton Island, mainland Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island, Scotland, Ireland, France, USA, England, Brazil and China. They have been featured internationally on television, radio and video and have performed in numerous Celtic Colours shows over the years. In 2008, Dawn and Margie were chosen as recipients of the Frank Sampson Award, given by the Celtic Colours Volunteer Drive'er Association to up-and-coming performers to help them record their first CD. Taste of Gaelic, a unique and traditional album that combines both traditional tunes and tunes composed by Dawn and Margie themselves, went on to win the 2010 East Coast Music Award in the category of Roots/Traditional Album of the Year for Group/Duo. Both Margie and Dawn are now part of an eight-piece dance troupe called Fileanta and perform regularly with that ensemble. If not playing or dancing, they are active within the cultural industries just the same. Dawn is the Artistic Director of Celtic Colours while Margie is the Marketing Director for Colaisde Na Gaidhlig in St. Ann's, Cape Breton. They continue to perform, teach and contribute to the island's culture.

470786.bio_limited: Donna Marie DeWolfe, of River Tillard near St. Peter’s in Richmond County, has been playing Cape Breton fiddle music since she was ten years old and comes from a line of musicians on both sides of her family. Her great-grandfather on her father’s side was a fiddler, while her grandfather on her mother’s side was both a fiddler and a fiddle maker. As a child, Donna Marie heard plenty of fiddle music in her home. Her father is a Cape Breton traditional music lover and he always had fiddle music playing in the house. Donna Marie is very active in the Cape Breton music scene, playing for ceilidhs and dances around the island and on the mainland. Donna Marie lists Shelly Campbell as a big influence on her playing as well as Donald Angus Beaton and Arthur Muise, having listened to many tapes of their vibrant playing.

470409.bio_limited: Joël Chiasson is a veteran piano player and step dancer from Cheticamp, Cape Breton. Citing Hilda Chiasson as his biggest influence, Joël has provided piano accompaniment on more than 25 recordings by artists including Natalie MacMaster, Ashley MacIsaac, Mary Jane Lamond, Buddy MacMaster and Andrea Beaton over the past 30 years. In the late 1990s, Joël toured extensively with Ashley MacIsaac and Natalie MacMaster. Over the years, Joël has taught Cape Breton style step dancing through workshops across Canada and the United States. Today Joël lives in Sydney with his family and works as a school teacher, but thankfully he still manages to get out and play for concerts and dances in and around Cape Breton.

470992.bio_limited: Eighteen-year-old Sarah MacInnis comes from West Mabou, Inverness County where she was exposed to traditional Cape Breton music since her earliest days. She comes from a musical family--mom Mary Elizabeth is a triple threat on fiddle, piano and dance, and grandfather Buddy MacMaster was a world renowned fiddler with humble roots in Judique. Sarah is certainly embodying the Gaelic way, as a gifted Gaelic singer, a lovely step dancer, and piano player. Sarah aspires to maintain the rich traditions and culture of her ancestors and has recently completed Na Gaisgich Òga, a Gaelic mentorship program offered by Colaisde na Gàidhlig (The Gaelic College) in St. Ann's. This is her third year performing at Celtic Colours.

143351.name: Women of Song

venue.name: SAERC (Strait Area Education Recreation Centre)
venue.google_maps_link: https://maps.google.com/?q=304 Pitt St, Unit 1 Port Hawkesbury, NS B9A 2T9 Canada

143351.description_public: Tonight we are honoured to present some very special voices dear to Celtic Colours and to the Island itself. Heather Rankin’s voice is certainly a familiar one as a member of Cape Breton band The Rankins. Multi- instrumentalist and singer Lucy MacNeil is also a familiar voice across Canada and around the world. Her crystalline vocals are immediately identifiable with her family band, the Barra MacNeils. And Irish singer and flute player Nuala Kennedy’s voice is always welcome around these parts. We are thrilled to include Joella Foulds in this concert celebrating Women of Song. Joella’s singing career started back in the 1970s when she moved to Cape Breton and met Rita MacNeil. After recording and touring with Rita for a few years, Joella shifted focus for awhile, but is now back to her first love of singing. Billie Yvette Rogers, a local singer-songwriter, rounds out tonight’s lineup. Nearby Meal: Fishcakes and Fiddles

484751.bio_limited: After more than twenty-five years of performing with her siblings, Heather Rankin comes into her own with A Fine Line, her JUNO-nominated debut solo record. This is Heather Rankin like you have never heard her before, breaking away from The Rankin Family’s signature sound, and forging her own musical legacy with her poetic, intimate original songs, and an eclectic mix of others. A Fine Line is an exploration of the balance between grief and joy, love and loss, and life and death. It is also a balance between Heather's musical past, present and future. Her voice has been shaped by the Gaelic traditions of her home, and by the years she spent singing the songs of her brothers and sisters, but her voice is set free here, suggesting that we are only just now getting to know Heather Rankin. She has always been known as the youngest of The Rankin Family, but now, as a solo artist, in some ways, she sounds younger, and more timely, than ever.

484751.name: Heather Rankin
484751.secondary_language_bio: After more than twenty-five years of performing with her siblings, Heather Rankin comes into her own with A Fine Line, her JUNO-nominated debut solo record. This is Heather Rankin like you have never heard her before, breaking away from The Rankin Family’s signature sound, and forging her own musical legacy with her poetic, intimate original songs, and an eclectic mix of others. A Fine Line is an exploration of the balance between grief and joy, love and loss, and life and death. It is also a balance between her own musical past, present and future. Her voice has been shaped by the Gaelic traditions of her home, and by the years she spent singing the songs of her brothers and sisters, but her voice is set free here, and often euphorically so, in a way previously unheard. Proving eloquent songwriting runs in the family, Rankin takes us to more private places in her lyrics, and this mixture of vulnerability and exhilaration makes for a powerfully compelling record. After more than twenty-five years in the business, A Fine Line suggests that we are only just now getting to know Heather Rankin. She has always been known as the youngest of The Rankin Family, but now, as a solo artist, in some ways, she sounds younger, and more timely, than ever.Heather makes her Celtic Colours debut this year.

470622.bio_limited: Lucy MacNeil recalls music as always being at the centre of her childhood home in Sydney Mines where family, neighbours and visiting musicians would often gather—the rhythm of everyone’s feet tapping with the music would lull her to sleep on many nights. The only girl in a family of five boys, Lucy may be described as the heart of The Barra MacNeils, the family band in which she sings (English and Gaelic), plays fiddle, harp and bodhran, and step dances. Her crystalline vocals are immediately identifiable with the group’s distinct sound. In a career spanning more than 30 years, The Barra’s have released 17 recordings and made fans of Cape Breton’s traditional music around the world. Lucy was one of the festival's Artist in Residence in 2015 and performs at Celtic Colours this year with guitar and bouzouki player Robert Durando.

470712.bio_limited: Nuala Kennedy is an Irish singer and flute player with hauntingly beautiful vocals, adventurous instrumentation, and an eclectic mix of influences. Her singing and flute playing springs from the traditional music of Ireland and Scotland, and from the fathomless realms of her own imagination. A consummate performer with a buoyant personality, her music has been described as unique, evocative, and soul-satisfying. Nuala grew up in Dundalk, Co. Louth, on the East coast of Ireland, a musical area steeped in mythology with long historical links to Scotland. The combination of the best influences of the two cultures, Scottish and Irish, is what has made Nuala the artist she is today. Nuala has been performing at Celtic Colours since 2002, first with Fine Friday, then on her own, with the Unusual Suspects of Celtic Colours, the Nuala Kennedy Trio, Oirialla, and the Snowflake Trio. This year, in addition to performing solo, Nuala introduces us to another group, The Alt, featuring a familiar face in John Doyle and, making his Celtic Colours debut, Eamon O’Leary.

471013.bio_limited: Joella Foulds was brought up on the Canadian Prairies. Her work as a singer goes back to the mid 1960s during the folk era, when she performed in folk clubs to help finance her education. Upon moving to Cape Breton in 1978, she met Rita MacNeil and they formed a band. Joella recorded on two of Rita’s early albums, touring with Rita as her backup singer and guitar-player for six years, performing in hundreds of shows from local pubs to huge festivals and theatres across Canada, and eventually writing and performing her own songs. For more than 20 years Joella put her performance career on hold as she co-founded and managed the Celtic Colours International Festival. Recently she has returned to the stage in musicals and as a solo performer, making her debut as a featured artist at Celtic Colours in 2016 with vibrant renditions of Rita’s songs “Home I’ll Be” and “Part of the Mystery” during the opening concert.

For more than 20 years Joella put her performance career on hold as she co-founded and managed the Celtic Colours International Festival. Recently she has returned to the stage in musicals and as a solo performer, making her debut as a featured artist at Celtic Colours in 2016 with vibrant renditions of Rita’s songs “Home I’ll Be” and “Part of the Mystery” during the opening concert.
471013.name: Joella Foulds
471013.secondary_language_bio:
Joella was brought up on the Canadian Prairies with music as a part of her everyday life from early childhood. Playing piano and singing came naturally and was encouraged by her parents. Her first professional work as a singer goes back to the mid 1960’s. A University student in the “folk” era, she performed solo and with others musicians in folk clubs and concerts as a way to help pay for her education.

In 1979, after moving to Cape Breton, she met Rita MacNeil who had recently returned home. Joella began accompanying her on guitar, singing harmonies and they eventually they formed a band. From 1979-1984 she worked with Rita as her backup singer and guitar player, performing in hundreds of shows with her ranging from local pubs to huge festivals and major theatres across Canada. She also backed Rita solo for many women’s concerts and began writing and performing her own songs at these events. By 1984 Joella was performing solo concerts at festivals and local events.

Musical Theatre opportunities included a tribute to Allistair MacGillivray called “Songs for the Mira” in 1984 and the role of Mistress of the Novices in Nunsense in 1985. The following year she co-created and performed two-women music and comedy show called “Broad Assumptions” with Bette MacDonald. In recent months she has returned to the stage in both musicals and theatre productions. In addition to music, Joella held a full time position with CBC Radio as a Broadcast Journalist and host of a daily current affairs show from 1979 to 1994.

For more than 20 years Joella put her performance career on hold as she worked on the industry side as an event manager and the co-founder of the Celtic Colours International Festival. She is thrilled to be on stage for the first time at Celtic Colours and paying tribute to her dear friend and mentor, Rita MacNeil.
471013.bio_with_line_breaks: Joella Foulds was brought up on the Canadian Prairies. Her work as a singer goes back to the mid 1960s during the folk era, when she performed in folk clubs to help finance her education. Joella recorded on two of Rita’s early albums, touring with Rita as her backup singer and guitar-player for six years, performing in hundreds of shows from local pubs to huge festivals and theatres across Canada, and eventually writing and performing her own songs. For more than 20 years Joella put her performance career on hold as she co-founded and managed the Celtic Colours International Festival. Recently she has returned to the stage in musicals and as a solo performer, making her debut as a featured artist at Celtic Colours in 2016 with vibrant renditions of Rita’s songs “Home I’ll Be” and “Part of the Mystery” during the opening concert.

489387.bio_limited: Singer-songwriter Billie Yvette Rogers is from North Sydney, Cape Breton Island. Her songs have interesting vocal melody arrangements, and thoughtful poetic lyrics. Her guitar style draws from a blend of folk, blues and country influences, and she creates memorable compositions. She has performed for the last decade around the Maritime Provinces, and has graced the stage solo, or as front-woman for the genre-blending band Billie Yvette Avenue (joined by Angelo Spinazzola, Alicia Penney, Ben Furey, Donnie Calabrese). Many folks know Yvette from her work in the administrative side of the arts sector. As the Outreach Coordinator for Celtic Colours she works with community groups that host Community Cultural Events during the festival, and programs a variety of outreach initiatives for youth and elders. She also works in community development as an independent facilitator. Songwriting is near and dear to Yvette's heart and a significant ingredient in her personal identity.

143352.name: Kelly's Dream

venue.name: Boularderie School
venue.google_maps_link: https://maps.google.com/?q=12065 Kempt Head Road Boularderie East, NS B1X 1J9 Canada

143352.description_public: Kelly is the hero of a popular Cape Breton song who “... left us Kelly’s Mountain to perpetuate his name”. The mountain itself is a Victoria County landmark overlooking the Great Bras d’Or. It has been an inspiration for local musicians, writers and artists alike, and is considered sacred ground by Cape Breton’s Mi’kmaq people. Boularderie School lies in the shadow of Kelly’s Mountain, and tonight it is the site of a concert in the mythical Irish character’s name. Award-winning traditional singer and bouzouki player Daoirí Farrell from Ireland is new to the Festival and The Narrows, led by Leanne Aucoin, features artists you’ve come to love through the years. They’ll be joined by Donnie Campbell and Jinks O’Neill to round out the night with some Cape Breton standards. It has always been presumed that Kelly would love music, and if that is so, we’re thinking tonight’s lineup just may be Kelly’s dream come true! Nearby Meal: Songs and Supper

491704.bio_limited: A former electrician, who decided to change profession after seeing Christy Moore perform on Irish TV, Dublin-born traditional singer and bouzouki player Daoirí (pronounced ‘Derry’) Farrell is being described by some of the biggest names in Irish folk music as one of most important singers to come out of Ireland in recent years, and has delivered the album to prove them right. Six months after releasing the album True Born Irishman Daoirí won two prestigious BBC Radio 2 Folk Awards 2017 for Best Newcomer and Best Traditional Track, and also performed live at the awards ceremony at London’s Royal Albert Hall.

470443.bio_limited: Donnie Campbell and Jinks (James) O'Neill started performing together in 2014. Both are from Sydney and grew up in musical households. They have travelled extensively with their music, Donnie with folk music and Jinks with rock and roll bands, giving them a vast repertoire of music from the folk revival, classic country, rock and roll of the 1950s and '60s as well as traditional music of Ireland, Scotland and Cape Breton. Donnie has been host of one of the longest running radio programs in Canadian history, Celtic Serenade, a run that is almost 45 years long. Hosted primarily on CJCB, the program made the move at the beginning of 2017 to The Coast and continues with listenership from all over the world. The program promotes not only Cape Breton music but that from the Celtic Diaspora.

The program promotes not only Cape Breton music but that from the Celtic Diaspora.
470443.name: Donnie Campbell & Jinks O'Neill
470443.secondary_language_bio:
Donnie Campbell was born into a musical family in Cape Breton. Since then he has enjoyed a long involvement in traditional music at various levels. He is a singer, collector and broadcaster, having hosted the popular radio program “Celtic Serenade”. In October of 2013, the program celebrated its 40th year, making it one of the longest running programs in Canadian Broadcasting history.

	In the early 1970’s, Donnie was a member of the popular Maritime folk group, Miller’s Jug. He has performed internationally and has shared the stage with people such as Tommy Makem, Scotland’s Phil Cunningham and the Tannahill Weavers, Ron Hynes, Evans & Dohety and John Allan Cameron. Although essentially a solo performer, Donnie has also worked at concerts and dances with Cape Breton fiddlers like Carl MacKenzie, Buddy MacMaster, Winnie Chafe, Jerry Holland and Kinnon Beaton just to name a few.

Donnie sings songs that matter to him, from love songs to stories of tragedy and good times and memories. His repertoire runs the course of the folk music revival, songs of Cape Breton, the ancient songs of Scotland and Ireland as well as more recent songs that keep the music fresh.
470443.bio_with_line_breaks:
Donnie Campbell and Jinks (James) O'Neill started performing together in 2014. Both are from Sydney and grew up in musical households. They have travelled extensively with their music, Donnie with folk music and Jinks with rock and roll bands, giving them a vast repertoire of music from the folk revival, classic country, rock and roll of the 1950s and '60s as well as traditional music of Ireland, Scotland and Cape Breton.
Donnie has been host of one of the longest running radio programs in Canadian history, Celtic Serenade, a run that is almost 45 years long. Hosted primarily on CJCB, the program made the move at the beginning of 2017 to The Coast and continues with listenership from all over the world. The program promotes not only Cape Breton music but that from the Celtic Diaspora.

486418.bio_limited: This Halifax-based quintet explores the fertile musical traditions of Eastern Canada. Blazing Newfoundland singles, quirky Quebec reels and driving Cape Breton jigs are all played from the heart, with a healthy dose of tunes from the musical motherlands of Ireland and Scotland thrown in for good measure. Leanne Aucoin (fiddle, piano, step dance) is steeped in the rich musical culture of Cape Breton where she learned her music from family members and mentors growing up in Sydney Mines. Colin Carrigan is one of the finest younger generation Newfoundland fiddle players, whose unique repertoire and lively style echo the vibrant musical culture of his home province. Jon Goodman, on uilleann pipes and wooden flute, is a sought-after Irish session player in Halifax, who has recorded and performed with East Coast musicians from Rita MacNeil to Joel Plaskett. Coming from a musical family in Weymouth, NS, singer and guitarist Jesse Lewis grew up playing in rock bands before turning his attention to accompanying fiddle players, with a style influenced by Cape Breton-style piano accompaniment. And originally from Quebec’s Eastern Townships, Roy MacLaren completes the lineup on tin whistles, tenor banjo, and his first instrument, highland bagpipes.

143353.name: Pjila'si: A Wagmatcook Welcome

venue.name: Wagmatcook Culture and Heritage Centre
venue.google_maps_link: https://maps.google.com/?q=10765 NS-105 Wagmatcook, NS B0E 3N0 Canada

143353.description_public: Pjila’si means welcome in Mi’kmaw and tonight we celebrate our fortune to have such welcoming First Nations communities on the Island. From the time the Scottish settlers first arrived here, they were shown true kindness by the Mi’kmaq people. Singer Evan Googoo will extend a welcome to visitors from near and far, including IVA, a throat-singer, poet and writer from Nunavut whose melodic mix of throat singing and poetry bridges sounds from both her Inuit and Irish- Cape Breton roots. George Paul, from the Metepenagiag First Nation in New Brunswick, may be best known for creating the “Mi’kmaq Honour Song”, but he’s been involved in reviving Mi’kmaq songs, chants and ceremonies for more than 30 years. And we’ll get our first taste of Scottish trio Talisk’s energetic and dynamic sound. Nearby Meals: Potluck Supper in Whycocomagh andSoul Food Supper in the same building as the evening concert.

488978.bio_limited: Kathleen Ivaluarjuk Merritt also known as IVA (ee-vah) will take you on a journey through the Arctic with vocal interpretations of the wind, birds, landscape and sea. Iva is a throat-singer, poet, writer and collaborator from Rankin Inlet, Nunavut who performs a melodic mix of Inuit throat singing and poetry infused with Celtic-influenced folk. Her 2015 debut album, Ivaluarjuk: Ice, Lines & Sealskin, celebrates life and identity; bridging sounds from both her Inuit and Irish roots. The music reaches a wide-range of sounds, crossing multiple genres that come together charmingly to transport audiences to the coasts of Cape Breton and Nunavut. When she is home in Nunavut, IVA works in schools and music programs to teach throat singing and facilitate workshops that encourage youth to create and collaborate, and build on their skills and confidence through music, art and identity.

492553.bio_limited: George was born in Metepenagiag First Nation (Red Bank) along the Miramichi River in New Brunswick. For more than 30 years, he has been involved with the Aboriginal Traditional Movement, working to revive Mi'kmaw songs, chants, and ceremonies. An East Coast Music Award winner, and creator of the "Mi'kmaq Honor Song", George organized the first Powwow at Red Bank First Nation in 1981. He has worked with numerous schools, universities and government organizations over the years to develop Mi'kmaw traditions customs and values including herbal and spiritual medicines, music, language, art and dance. George has been involved with theatre, song, dance and traditional teachings for a long time and is able to communicate powerful cultural teachings to any age with his signature singing voice, honest good humour and a wealth of cultural knowledge and lived experience that engages everyone around him. In his delightfully lighthearted way, George shares deeply moving stories and gains his audience's participation through music and discussion.

492104.bio_limited: BBC Radio 2 Folk Award winners Talisk are one of the fastest rising bands on the UK folk scene. Mohsen Amini (concertina), Hayley Keenan (fiddle) and Graeme Armstrong (guitar) create a captivating, energetic and dynamic sound that has earned them multiple awards and nationwide media and audience attention. Alongside their collective plaudits, Amini was named the 2016 BBC Radio Scotland Young Traditional Musician of the Year, adding to their already bursting trophy cabinet that far belies their years. So too does their gigging history – with appearances at world-leading festivals including the Cambridge Folk Festival, Denmark’s Tønder, Fairport’s Cropredy Convention, both the Orkney and Shetland Folk Festivals and Celtic Connections, as well as live sessions on both BBC Radio 2 and BBC Radio Scotland’s flagship folk programmes, and tours afoot in many areas of Europe and across the Atlantic. Theirs is a star firmly, and rapidly, on the ascent.

471050.bio_limited: Singer, drummer and guitarist Evan Googoo was born in the small First Nation community of Wagmatcook, located right in the middle of Cape Breton Island. He remembers his grandfather playing fiddle and uncle playing guitar around the house when he was a kid. A self-taught guitar player, he discovered music for himself in junior high and high school, putting a band together in the nearby community of Eskasoni, where he went to school for grade 12. They played around at local events and gatherings before graduating and going their separate ways. Evan would pick up the guitar again years later and has since started a program teaching free guitar lessons at the school for any of the kids who want to learn how to play guitar. Music is much more than picking up an instrument and playing to Evan. He credits playing music with helping him overcome heartache and tragedy, helping with his confidence and to grow as a person.

143363.name: Saturday Night at the Savoy

venue.name: Savoy Theatre
venue.google_maps_link: https://maps.google.com/?q=116 Commercial Street Glace Bay, NS B1A 3C1 Canada

143363.description_public:
This Saturday night at the Savoy you will be treated to one of folk music’s busiest trios, McGoldrick, McCusker and Doyle. From touring with the likes of Bob Dylan, Mark Knopfler
and Joan Baez to being founding or long-time members of legendary groups Flook, Lunasa, Battlefield Band and Solas, these three lads have been at the forefront of trad music’s evolution, and play key roles in the BBC Transatlantic Sessions series. Another regular collaborator to that acclaimed series is Phil Cunningham who returns with Ùr: The Future of our Past. Virtuoso Cape Breton fiddler Dwayne Côté will share some tunes, and the Men of the Deeps, North America’s only coal miners chorus, will share some of their many songs and stories. The night wouldn’t be complete without some dancing. The award-winning MacArthur Dancers, no strangers to the 90-year-old Savoy stage, will show us some steps to make it just so.

471643.bio_limited: From touring with the likes of Bob Dylan, Mark Knopfler and Joan Baez to being founding or long-time members of legendary groups Flook, Lunasa, Battlefield Band and Solas, Michael McGoldrick, John McCusker and John Doyle have been at the forefront of traditional and folk music for decades. Key members of the acclaimed BBC Transatlantic Sessions, the trio has recently released their second record, giving us all a rare chance to see three of the world’s finest musicians share a stage together. Master of flutes, whistles and uillean pipes McGoldrick is a founding member of Flook and Lunasa, and is a current member of Capercaillie. Regarded as one of the greatest flute players of all time, McGoldrick has toured with Bob Dylan and Mark Knopfler, among many others. John McCusker’s unique fiddle playing has earned him a worldwide reputation as one of the most gifted and versatile musicians of any genre. Renowned for his skill at transcending musical boundaries, McCusker—also part of the band that toured with Dylan and Knopfler—spent 11 years touring the world with the legendary Battlefield Band. John Doyle’s gifts as guitarist, songwriter and vocalist have played an essential role in the ongoing renaissance of Irish traditional music. A past Artist in Residence at Celtic Colours (2012), Doyle was musical director for Joan Baez and toured with her for two years. One half of the stellar duo Liz Carroll and John Doyle, he is also a founding member of the internationally acclaimed Irish group Solas.

471039.bio_limited: Ùr literally means "new". This exciting new group of students from the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland are a handpicked showcase of some of the exceptional talent and skills being nurtured by the dedicated staff of the traditional music degree course in Glasgow.  Following great success performing at last year’s festival, the band is thrilled to be returning to Celtic Colours in 2017. These students learn about the traditions behind this wonderful musical culture, and are taught how to embrace and protect these traditions, whilst breathing new life into them and keeping them very much alive. With performance skills a priority throughout the degree, real virtuosity is being discovered amongst these players and singers. Their love of the music is obvious in their passionate and energetic performance and thoughtful, exciting arrangements. Led by guitarist Jenn Butterworth (Scots Trad 2015 Tutor of the Year), these talented musicians are delighted to bring another glimpse of Scotland’s finest music back to Cape Breton.

494644.bio_limited: Award-winning Scottish accordion player, composer, and arranger Phil Cunningham returns to Celtic Colours this year with Ùr: The Future of our Past, a handpicked group of students from the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland. A superb, innovative instrumentalist, with not simply the fastest fingers in the West but some of the most sensitive ones, Phil is no stranger to Celtic Colours. A past Artist in Residence at Celtic Colours (2005), Phil composed the tune “Colours of Cape Breton” during his first visit to the Festival in 2001. This will be Phil’s seventh time playing at Celtic Colours, and whether he’s here with his trio, with Shetland fiddler and long-time musical partner Aly Bain, or with the students from the Royal Conservatoire, this Member of the Order of the British Empire never fails to delight audiences with his masterful playing and irrepressible sense of humour. It’s always a pleasure to welcome Phil back to Cape Breton and Celtic Colours.

470434.bio_limited: The Men of the Deeps is a choir of working and retired coal miners from Cape Breton Island. For more than 50 years the singing miners have donned their signature overalls and helmets to sing about the work and life of Cape Breton’s miners. Their work preserving some of the rich folklore of the island’s coal mining communities has taken them far and wide, and they have found kinship wherever in the world hard-working men make a living underground. The Men of the Deeps have released nine albums, been the subject of two National Film Board of Canada films and one book, toured around the world, and frequently been featured on TV and radio. A songbook featuring choral arrangements for some of the group's most popular songs has also been published. Today the Men of the Deeps are more than a singing group - it is a social institution. There is a camaraderie amongst the members of the group that carries over to their audiences wherever they perform.

470402.bio_limited: Fiddler and composer Dwayne Côté was raised in a family deeply rooted in all aspects of Cape Breton, Irish and Scottish music traditions--his mother being a renowned dancer, instructor, and performer and his father, the late Gordon Côté, a celebrated fiddler and teacher. An international professional musician, Dwayne has been performing since he was four years old and has played all over the world from Cape Breton to Dubai, and Scotland to Australia. A composer with more than 200 tunes registered with SOCAN, he is recognized as one of the most unique violinists and fiddlers in Atlantic Canada who can easily slide from style to style. Although rooted in the Cape Breton style of fiddling, he can transition to classical and jazz seemingly effortlessly. Dwayne has many albums to his credit along with various nominations including an ECMA nomination for Traditional Instrumental recording of the year in 2013.

470833.bio_limited: The MacArthur Dancers are a dance troupe from Cape Breton Island. The group promotes their strong ties and love of the Island's Gaelic and Scottish culture by bringing creative traditional dance choreography to stages all over the world. Directed by champion Highland Dancer and veteran Cape Breton step dancer Kelly MacArthur, the troupe has been running for 20 years, producing four generations of performers from all over Cape Breton. Top level Premier Dancers, they have performed all over Canada--winning awards, championships, and scholarships in traditional dance and Choreography--and are heading to Scotland in August to compete at the World Highland Dance Championships. They have performed with The Barra MacNeils, Summertime Revue, Mary Jane Lamond & Wendy MacIsaac, and Sprag Session, and also appeared on the tv program The Amazing Race Canada and at the Casino Nova Scotia Music Hall of Fame Gala. The MacArthur Dancers have been performing at Celtic Colours for numerous years, and are thrilled to be invited again this year.

470833.secondary_language_bio: (2016 - 100 words) Kelly MacArthur is a champion dancer from Cape Breton, who has competed and performed all over the world and taught Highland and Cape Breton Step Dance for the past 25 years, including 15 years at her own Dance Studio in Sydney, the MacArthur School of Dance. The school has a performance troupe called the CapeLand Dancers which consists of top level dancers from all over Cape Breton. Performing highland and step dance along with Kelly this year at Dancing Up a Suête, are both junior and senior members of the Company, all of whom are seasoned performers and top-notch dancers.

148191.price: $20 / $10 with concert ticket stub from that day
148191.description_public: One of the most popular features of the Celtic Colours International Festival every year is the Festival Club. Located at the Gaelic College in St. Ann's, the licensed Festival Club opens as the evening concerts are closing, offering an opportunity for artists to showcase in a more informal setting, as well as get a session in with friends and colleagues from near and far. It also serves as a spot to wind down at the end of the day. Performance is by invitation only and depends upon artist availability on any given night. The performance schedule is not posted in advance. North Shore singer-songwriter Buddy MacDonald hosts the nightly festivities. Tickets are half price for those holding a ticket stub from a Celtic Colours performance that day. *Restricted to 19 years and over. Picture ID required.

143354.name: Pipers' Ceilidh
143354.venue_name: Colaisde na Gàidhlig / The Gaelic College

venue.name: Colaisde na Gàidhlig / The Gaelic College
venue.google_maps_link: https://maps.google.com/?q=51779 Cabot Trail  St. Ann's, NS B0C 1H0 Canada

143354.description_public: One of Celtic Colours’ most endearing concerts each year is the Pipers’ Ceilidh. This year’s concert takes a long look back at the tradition behind the pipes, and how that tradition is being studied, absorbed and brought into the future. Seudan features four vibrant young Highland bagpipers, anchored by the traditional piper and Gaelic singer Allan MacDonald, who comes from a well-revered piping family. They offer lively pipe music, rooted in the step dancing traditions long lost to Scotland, but that continue to this day on Cape Breton. Nuallan, a group of local pipers formed by Colaisde Na Gàidhlig, have dedicated themselves to representing, promoting and exploring the dance style of piping brought from Scotland by Highland Gaels and developed here over the past two hundred years. In recognition of the ties between the piping traditions of Scotland and Cape Breton Island, pipes made by celebrated craftsman Hamish Moore will be presented to the Gaelic College during this concert. Get your tickets early! Nearby Meal: St. Ann’s Thanksgiving Dinner

470688.bio_limited: Seudan, founded by Hamish Moore, features the Scottish piping prowess of Fin Moore, Angus MacKenzie (originally of Mabou, Cape Breton), Angus Nicolson, Calum MacCrimmon, and Allan MacDonald. Pronounced "Shay-tan", the group consists of four vibrant young Highland bagpipers, anchored by the traditional piper and Gaelic singer Allan MacDonald, who comes from a well-revered piping family, rich in culture. Together they offer lively pipe music, rooted in the step dance traditions, now revived in Scotland with the indispensable help and inspiration of the unbroken line of the tradition in Cape Breton.

470853.bio_limited: Comprised of three Cape Breton pipers – Keith MacDonald, Kenneth MacKenzie, and Kevin Dugas – and formed by the Gaelic College, Nuallan seeks to represent, promote and explore the style of piping brought from Scotland by Highland Gaels and developed over the past two hundred years here on Cape Breton Island. This rich style of playing has a strong focus on rhythm and musicality and displays a strong connection to the song and dance traditions of Gaelic culture. Nuallan’s members are well known individually for their rhythmic, musical playing and bringing them together to celebrate the importance of these connections was a natural fit. The group has released one album and their high-energy performances are a hit wherever they play.

143357.name: Dancing Up a Suête
143357.venue_name: La Place des arts Père Anselme Chiasson

venue.name: La Place des arts Père Anselme Chiasson
venue.google_maps_link: https://maps.google.com/?q=15118 Cabot Trail  Cheticamp, NS B0E 1H0 Canada

143357.description_public: Chéticamp is a culturally rich and vibrant Acadian community located along the Cabot Trail on Cape Breton Island’s northwest coast, where the south-east winds, known as les suêtes, blow strong onshore and dancing is practically second nature. For 20 years La Swing du Suête dance troupe, comprised of students at L’École NDA in Chéticamp, has been promoting and presenting Acadian Cape Breton dance here at home and across the Maritimes, in Quebec, Alberta and Louisiana. Christine Doucette is Artistic Director and handles choreography along with Sylvie Doucette, both former dancers with the troupe. Bon Débarras will bring their energetic music and dance from Quebec to this afternoon’s celebration. And Andrea, Véronique, Douglas and Lawrence, all well- versed in the Acadian and Québécois dance traditions, will provide the tunes and tempos needed for these dancers to show their steps

470615.bio_limited: La Swing du Suête initially came together in 1997 for the first annual Cape Breton Dance Festival in Chéticamp. Over the last twenty years, La Swing du Suête has presented itself across the Maritime provinces as well as in Quebec, Alberta and Louisiana, USA. Under the artistic direction of Christine Doucet and Sylvie Aucoin, the troupe continues to enchant audiences with their choreographies, their dance steps, and particularly their charm. This troupe is comprised of dancers ranging in age from 10 to 17 all students at École NDA in Chéticamp. Celtic Colours celebrates the group's 20th anniversary in the annual dance show in Cheticamp, Dancing Up a Suête and in the opening show, We Walk as One.

470382.bio_limited: Andrea Beaton comes from a long line of musicians, composers and dancers. She is an award-winning fiddler, tune composer and recording artist who is known for her powerful bow and driving style. She tours and teaches internationally and is in great demand as a teacher at music camps and fiddling/dancing workshops. Andrea has released six solo albums, one duo album with her father, Kinnon Beaton, and published three books of her original tunes. She also recorded an album with her family The Beaton Family of Mabou in 2007 for the Smithsonian Institute. Most of her solo albums were nominated for awards, including her latest, Andrea Beaton with Betty and Dave (2016), and her 2010 CD, Branches, won the East Coast Music Award for Instrumental Recording of the Year. Andrea travels the globe, sharing her culture as well as exploring and writing contemporary tunes. Her music, dance and comical stories are sure to delight any audience.

494513.bio_limited: Véronique Plasse is a tour de force of music. A leading proponent of the traditional music and songs of Québec, she performs internationally and works hard to preserve, uplift and propel the cultural family of her francophone nation. Her repertoire of traditional Québecois music is bolstered by her own original tunes, and she is recognized for her sweet and fearless improvisational style. Create, collect and transmit are the three verbs that lead her artistic career. But her main interest of all is meeting you! Véronique is also part of the group Panache Quartet who performed at the 2014 edition of Celtic Colours. Véronique will perform with fellow Panache member Andrea Beaton at this year's festival.
